makers.displaydate: 1869–1965; born Bridgeville, DE; died Centre Bridge, PA
makers.displaymaker: Edward Willis Redfield, 1869–1965; born Bridgeville, DE; died Centre Bridge, PA

texts.textentryhtml: The artist; Mary Eva Moore Sherrerd and William D. Sherrerd, Haddonfield, New Jersey, by 1927; Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sherrerd Jr., Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, by ca. 1960; Mr. and Mrs. John J.F. Sherrerd, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, by 1987; Estate of Mr. John J.F. Sherrerd, Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, 2008; Anne C. Sherrerd, Riverside, Connecticut, 2011; gifted to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2024.

Redfield was a founder and mainstay of the Pennsylvania Impressionists, a group of mostly landscape artists active during the first half of the twentieth century in and around the Bucks County town of New Hope. Spring Landscape, painted at the height of Redfield’s career, depicts the Delaware River looking toward New Jersey from Point Pleasant, a hamlet north of New Hope, where the artist kept a second studio. From there he set out in all seasons to produce ambitious plein air paintings in his signature style of bold, vigorous brushwork and sophisticated color harmonies. Although Redfield is renowned for his portrayal of winter landscapes, the freshness of the artist’s approach seems especially apt for this springtime scene. The painting is distinguished by its custom-made frame designed by Bernard Badura (1896—1986), a New Hope artist and craftsman who supplied many of the Pennsylvania Impressionists with frames sympathetic to their typically vigorous work.

Mary Eva Moore Sherred and William D. Sherrerd, Haddonfield (NJ), BY 1927; inherited by Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sherrerd Jr., Bryn Mawr (PA), by ca. 1960; inherited by Mr. and Mrs. John J. F. Sherrerd, Bryn Mawr (PA), by 1987; Estate of Mr. John J. F. Sherrerd, Bryn Mawr (PA), 2008; inherited by Anne C. Sherrerd, Riverside (CT), 2011; donated to the Princeton University Art Museum, 2024.
